Award.AwardTitle: Spatially Localized Structures in Higher Dimension
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a proposal to study spatially localized structures in driven dissipative systems. Such structures are characterized by a balance between energy input through suitable forcing and energy dissipation within the structure, and are common in many physical systems including fluids, nonlinear optics and reaction-diffusion equations. This proposal seeks to extend existing understanding of these structures to two and three spatial dimensions through mathematical analysis of global bifurcations in spatially reversible systems together with numerical continuation techniques. Systems with both variational and nonvariational structure will be studied, with a focus on understanding the growth and multiplicity of stationary or moving structures as parameters are varied. Time-dependent localized structures will be studied through analysis of the bulk state and the motion of the front or boundary that confines it. Collisions between moving structures and their trapping by external inhomogeneities will be investigated by direct numerical simulation. The results will be applied to several systems exhibiting thermally driven motion including binary fluid convection, doubly diffusive convection and rotating convection.

Spatially localized structures are common in physical systems. Familiar examples in fluids include localized convection, vortices, liquid drops and solitary waves. Additional examples are provided by spots in optical and chemical systems, localized buckling of slender structures under compression, pulses propagating along neural fibers and localized oscillations in vibrating granular media. Although these examples reach across many areas of the physical sciences the localized structures that appear have many properties in common. This proposal seeks to develop a mathematical understanding of the origin and properties of such structures focusing on changes that take place as the parameters of the system change, and aims to identify the properties that are shared by these different examples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This is a project to improve our understanding of spatially localized structures in systems with more than one spatial dimension. Systems described by partial differential equations were studied and the theory developed, including numerical continuation based on spectral elements, was applied to several important systems arising in hydrodynamics: (i) convection in a horizontal layer rotating about the vertical, (ii) convection in an imposed magnetic field and (iii) doubly diffusive convection driven by disparities between the diffusion rates of heat and salt that arises in oceanographic applications. In general stationary localized structures in systems of this type are organized in several intertwined solution branches within a parameter region called the snaking region, and this is so in both one, two and three dimensions. The PI and colleagues discovered, however, that the detailed properties of the snaking branches depend on the absence or presence of a conserved quantity. In (i) this quantity is the zonal momentum while in (ii) it is the magnetic flux across the layer that is conserved. These results were confirmed in a detailed study of a model problem, the so-called conserved Swift-Hohenberg equation, that models the growth of a crystalline solid from a supercooled melt. In particular we find that localized structures in conserved systems exhibit slanted snaking and that such structures are present both in the subcritical and supercritical regimes, the former referring to the case in which the melt and crystal coexist stably, and the latter to the case where the melt is already unstable.

The PI has used this and more sophisticated models to study the properties of crystallization fronts whereby the crystalline state invades the supercooled liquid. He showed that this process deposits a crystal whose wavelength does not correspond to the state of minimium energy, the preferred state in thermodynamic equilibrium. As a result, once the front has passed the crystalline state left behind 'ages', i.e., it breaks up into domains with the thermodynamically preferred wavelength, thereby introducing defects and domain walls into the system. This why ice generated by rapid freezing is opaque whereas ice generated by slow freezing is transparent. The PI has studied the question whether over time the defects will heal or whether the disorder remains frozen into the crystal. He has also found that in systems with a two-scale interparticle potential the competition between these scales may create crystals with quasicrystalline order. Such structures have a simple diffraction pattern that resembles that of periodic crystals but are in fact nonperiodic. This may happen when the melt is unstable with respect to perturbations with one scale but the nonlinear processes that select the crystal structure favor a different lengthscale. The PI has used this process to identify specific conditions leading to (soft matter) quasicrystals in both two and three dimensions. The 12-fold quasicrystals found in two dimensions do not correspond to a global energy minimum, however, and so are expected to be metastable at finite temperature. In contrast, in three dimensions the PI identified a system where an icosahedral quasicrystal is the global energy minimum and so is stable at finite temperature (see accompanying figure).

The PI has also studied spatially localized traveling pulses, and constructed a rational model of the regime corresponding to the transition to turbulence in simple shear flows. This model facilitates the computation of the finite amplitude streamwise vortex structures that coexist with stable laminar flow in such systems and may prove useful in future studies of spatially localized structures in such flows, ie., turbulence precursors. Finally, the PI also initiated a study of localized structures in systems with time-periodic forcing and discovered a resonance between the timescale on which such structures grow and the period of the forcing. Applications of the theory developed to explain these findings are expected in ecology where models describing vegetation cover under stressed conditions generally ignore seasonal changes in growth conditions.

For the above reasons the project is expected to impact current thinking about crystallization, glassy materials and the requirements for the formation of quasicrystals within both the physics and materials communities, while other aspects of the work may impact ecology and other areas of science where spatially extended systems are of interest and time-dependent forcing prevails.

The project resulted in the publication of 25 papers. One student received his PhD with partial support from the grant, and a postdoctoral research associate also worked on the project supported from the grant. The PI also supervised the research of an undergraduate student that is expected to lead to a publication. The results of the project were presented at a number of international conferences and in seminars and colloquia at several universities.
